results.title: Without anesthesia = Bez znieczulenia [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Andrzej Wajda, Barbara Pec-Slesicka and Film Polski
results.brief_description: A deeply moving film by the renowned Polish director, Andrzej Wajda (Man of marbles, Korczak, Danton) of one man’s life seemingly falling apart around him. Jerzy Michalowski (Zbigniew Zapasiewicz), a well-known Polish international journalist unwittingly upsets the Polish authorities with his knowledge and political commentary on world affairs, and Polish affairs, on national television. Upon returning from an assignment abroad, Jerzy suddenly finds his privileges have been cut back, his next course at the university cancelled and his next trip no longer necessary. At the same time as his career appears to be crumbling apart, Jerzy’s wife has also decided to leave him for a younger colleague. Fundamentally a sympathetic character, the film follows Jerzy on his downward spiral as his whole world collapses in front of him. A story which subliminally hits out at the Polish system, but primarily a story of human relationships containing an interesting blend of drama, tragedy and humour. In Polish with English subtitles. Cast also includes Ewa Datkowska, Andrzej Seweryn, Krystyna Janda, Roman Wilhelmi. (Awards: Cannes Film Festival 1979; Polish Film Festival 1978)

results.title: Korczak [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Andrzej Wajda, Wolfgang Hantke and Studio Filmowe "Perspektwa"
results.brief_description: Korczak is a biopic of Jan Korczak (played by Wojciech Pszoniak), a highly respected children’s doctor and author of children’s books in Poland who earned the status of a saint after he accompanied 300 Jewish orphans to the gas chamber in Treblinka. Set in Warsaw between 1936-42, “Korczak” reveals the rise of German occupation within the city and the segregation of Jews from non-Jews. The degradation of Jews within the city-streets at the hands of the Germans is harrowing, and heightened by the use of archive newsreel footage. Korczak establishes an orphanage for the city’s lost Jewish children and works to protect them against the encroaching threat of Nazi Germany. He is revealed to be a man of enormous compassion, with a ceaseless capacity to nurture and provide, and the ultimate selflessness to accompany the children to their inevitable death. Evocatively shot in black and white by Robby Muller, with a script by Agnieszka Holland and directed by established Polish director, Andrzej Wajda, “Korczak” is a deeply moving story about the unspeakable horrors of the Holocaust and the choice to face racial discrimination and genocide with dignity and resolve. The film’s finale, however, provides one of the most magical sequences in the history of cinema. In Polish with English subtitles. Cast includes Wojciech Pszoniak, Ewa Dalkowska.

results.title: The Shop on Main Street = The Shop on the high street = Obchad na korze (NTSC)
results.creator_credit: Elmar Klos, Jan Kadar, Ceskoslovensky Filmexport and Filmove Studio Barrandov
results.brief_description: The film is set during World War II in the ‘independent’ fascist Slovak statelet. It concerns Tono Brtko, a carpenter who is appointed ‘Aryan controller’ of a button shop by his fascist brother-in-law. The shop is owned by the Jewish Frau Lautmann, who is not only elderly, but deaf and short-sighted, and thinks that Tono is her new assistant. Through a mixture of weakness, vacillation and decency, he fails to disabuse her, and a mutually beneficial relationship develops. This is an extraordinarily effective picture of ‘everyday fascism’ in a small community, and although it revolves around a grim and tragic theme, it is played largely as a gentle comedy. Cast includes Ida Kaminska, Jozef Kroner, Hana Slivkova, Frantisek Zvarik. In Czech with English subtitles.

results.title: A Soldier's story [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Patrick Palmer, Ronald L Schwary, Caldix Films and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Director Norman Jewison explores themes in “A Soldier’s story” similar to his Academy Award-winning “In the Heat of the Night”. It is World War II and an all black platoon at a Georgia army base spends its time finessing their baseball skills while awaiting the go-ahead to join the war effort. They’re led by the sadistic, incendiary Sergeant Vernon Waters, who rules the platoon with an iron fist and shouts harsh, racist comments even though he himself is an African-American. “A Soldier’s story” begins with the mysterious murder of Waters and then traces the investigation of the crime by black officer, Captain Davenport. Though Davenport suspects two white soldiers of killing Waters, his instincts are proven wrong and the real killer is a dramatic and moving surprise. “A Soldier’s story” is a well-crafted drama that raises the important issue of race relations in America and how racism and discrimination find their way in such official institutions as the military. In fact, the film shows how the military’s power structure supports the abuse of power and iron force rule. Its message overall is bleak: in this microcosmic world of the army, racial discrimination has led to a split in the notion of brotherhood among black men in America with Sergeant Waters internalising and projecting racial conflict on his blood brothers. Cast includes Howard E. Rollins Jr., Adolph Caesar, Art Evans, Denzel Washington and Wings Hauser. Music score by Herbie Hancock.

results.title: Ariel. Hamlet goes business
results.brief_description: Two feature films from Finnish filmmaker Aki Kaurismaki. “Ariel”: Propelled by the closure of the local mine and faced with unemployment Taisto Kasurinen (Turo Pajala) sets off in his Cadillac across the bleak and wintery Finnish landscape into the depressed industrial towns. In search of work and love he meets Irmeli (Susanna Haavisto) and together they express their desire for love with emotional efficiency. The soundtrack of popular 50s and 60s romance tunes expresses the love that our protagonists are incapable of expressing. Signalling hope, Kaurismaki finds humanity in the most bleak of places and with characters whose lives are filled with much hardship and hurt, managing to create a film that bubbles with affection. “Hamlet goes business”: This second black comedy reprises Shakespeare’s Hamlet into a contemporary setting where bitter family rivalry, revenge and greed are the order of the day. A brutish father is poisoned while plots are hatched to extract his millions. But this evil family has no plan and gradually the double-crossing characters fall victim to their own vices. A farcical take on the classic with Kaurismaki’s trademark deadpan humour. Combined cast includes: Turo Pajala, Susanna Haavisto, Matti Pellonpaa, Eetu Hilkamo, Pirkka-Pekka Petelius, Eskoski Salminen, Kati Outinen, Elina Salo, Esko Nikkari, Kari Vaananen, Turo Pajala, Matti Pei.

results.title: I Hired a contract killer. The Match factory girl
results.creator_credit: Aki Kaurismaki, Swedish Film Institute and Villealfa Filmproductions
results.brief_description: Aki Kaurismaki’s films have been described as “Ealing comedies on downers” (Timeout). Presented here are two features from the director, producer, writer and editor. Kaurismaki’s films capture a deadpan humour framed within a melancholic society where the protagonists, as if frozen, become still lives perfectly matched to the poverty of their environment (captured by the superb cinematography of Timo Salminen). Set in London (and in the English language), “I Hired a contract killer” is a slow meditation on loneliness and isolation within a dehumanised industrial setting. After fifteen years of loyal service to his company, Henri Boulanger (Jean-Pierre Leaud), a lone migrant, is fired on the spot. In his despair he hires a contract killer after several unsuccessful attempts at suicide. But best laid plans can go wrong…almost immediately after arranging the contract, Henri’s faith in humanity is restored when he falls in love with Margaret (Margi Clarke), another loner. Henri is now in a race against time as he endeavors to have his contract cancelled. (Cast includes: Joe Strummer, Serge Reggiani). “The Match factory girl” (in Swedish language with English subtitles) is the modern Cinderella tale without the Hollywood ending. Iris (Kati Outinen) works in a factory supporting her cruel mother and stepfather. Her dreams of escaping the life are shattered when ‘love’ turns out to be another part of the misery. Numbed by the present and burdened by her past, Iris’s rage catapults her into the future.

results.title: Welcome to Sarajevo
results.creator_credit: Michael Winterbottom, Damian Jones, Graham Broadbent, Channel Four Television and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: Based on a true story, “Welcome To Sarajevo” is a rare example of the war genre, one prepared to indict the western world for its refusal to aid the victims of a modern warzone like the former Yugoslavia. British journalist Michael Henderson (Stephen Dillane) begins a series of reports on a Muslim orphanage where dozens of children are trapped without food or medical support. His reports become pleas for help and finally scathing editorials before he takes matters into his own hands. Director Michael Winterbottom is careful not to paint Henderson as a hero, but rather the most ordinary of people forced to react against a heartless international community. With a cast that also includes Kerry Fox, Woody Harrelson and Marisa Tomei, “Welcome To Sarajevo” is a different approach to the war genre - one in which no one involved is morally black or white.

results.title: The Road home [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Zhang Yimou, Zhao Yu and Guangxi Film Studio
results.brief_description: After the death of his father, Luo returns home to his village to help his mother with funeral arrangements. On his arrival he learns of his mother’s wish for a traditional burial for his father - something that has not been performed in the village for hundred of years. It is a costly and exhausting ceremony and Luo does not understand why they can’t have a simple funeral. Told in flashbacks, “The Road home” recounts Luo’s parents romance and how they captivated the village with their undying love for one other. Directed by Zhang Yimou (“Raise the Red Lantern”, “Not One Less”) and starring Zhang Ziyi (“Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon”), this is a beautiful tale of love and undeniable passion.

results.title: All over me
results.creator_credit: Alex Sichel, Dolly Hall, Baldini Pictures, Medusa Pictures and Slam Pictures
results.brief_description: Fifteen year old Claude (Alison Folland) works part time in a pizza shop, lives with her mother in a small apartment in Hell’s Kitchen and loves to jam with her best friend Ellen (Tara Subcoff). However, Claude’s world is starting to change; Claude realises that she has developed stronger feelings for Ellen. Ellen is spending less time with Claude because she has a new boyfriend, Mark, whose aggression and homophobia alienate Claude. Luke (Pat Briggs), a gay musician, has moved into her apartment block and encourages Claude’s interest in music and the world she lives in. When Claude meets Lucy (Leisha Hailey from The Murmers), her recognition of her homosexuality comes to the fore. However, Claude’s world and the people in it are careering out of control; violence abounds and Claude witnesses Ellen’s increasingly complex relationship with drugs. The Sichel sisters, Alex (director) and Sylvia (writer) have created a rites-of-passage film about coming out and growing up in the unforgiving environment of Hell’s Kitchen. The desultory mood of the film and the subtle performance of Folland as Claude launches a dramatic debut feature for the Sichel sisters. (Awards: Winner, Gay Teddy bear at the 1997 Berlin Film Festival)
